skill.name: biomni
skill.description: Autonomous biomedical AI agent framework for executing complex research tasks across genomics, drug discovery, molecular biology, and clinical analysis. Use this skill when conducting multi-step biomedical research including CRISPR screening design, single-cell RNA-seq analysis, ADMET prediction, GWAS interpretation, rare disease diagnosis, or lab protocol optimization. Leverages LLM reasoning with code execution and integrated biomedical databases.
skill.summary: Autonomous biomedical AI agent framework for executing complex research tasks across genomics, drug ...
skill.author: K-Dense Inc.

security_audit.summary: This skill provides documentation and helper scripts for the biomni biomedical AI framework. The setup script runs external commands (conda) and writes API keys to .env files, which are legitimate setup operations but expand the attack surface. No evidence of obfuscation, credential theft, or malicious network calls.

medium_findings.title: Setup script runs external commands
medium_findings.description: The setup script executes external binaries and a generated test script using subprocess.run(). Example from line 67-69: "subprocess.run(['conda', 'create', '-n', 'biomni_e1', 'python=3.10', '-y'], check=True)". If a malicious binary is earlier in PATH, an attacker could run arbitrary code under the user account. This is a standard setup pattern but requires PATH hygiene.

low_findings.title: API keys saved in plaintext .env
low_findings.description: API keys are written to disk in plaintext format. From lines 145-149: "with open(env_file, 'w') as f:" followed by "f.write(f\"{key}={value}\\n\")". If the directory is shared, backed up insecurely, or accessed by other users, credentials could be exposed. Users should set restrictive file permissions (chmod 600) on .env files.

content.value_statement: Biomedical research tasks require multi-step analysis across many data sources. Biomni provides structured workflows to design CRISPR screens, analyze single-cell data, predict drug properties, and interpret genetic variants using large language models.
actual_capabilities: Design CRISPR knockout screens with sgRNA library generation and gene prioritization
Analyze single-cell RNA-seq data with quality control, clustering, and cell type annotation
Predict ADMET properties for drug candidates including absorption and toxicity
Interpret GWAS results and map variants to causal genes with pathway enrichment
Generate PDF reports from conversation histories and analysis results
Configure API keys for multiple LLM providers including Claude, OpenAI, and Google
limitations: Requires external biomni package installation via pip
Requires LLM provider API keys to execute real research tasks
Downloads approximately 11GB of biomedical databases on first use
PDF report generation requires additional dependencies like weasyprint

use_cases.title: Design CRISPR screens
use_cases.description: Plan sgRNA libraries and prioritize genes for functional genomics screens.

use_cases.title: Analyze single cell data
use_cases.description: Run quality control, clustering, and cell type annotation for scRNA-seq datasets.

use_cases.title: Assess ADMET risks
use_cases.description: Summarize absorption, metabolism, and toxicity predictions for compound libraries.

prompt_templates.title: Gene overview
prompt_templates.prompt: Explain the main functions of the BRCA1 gene and list key associated diseases.

prompt_templates.title: CRISPR screen plan
prompt_templates.prompt: Design a CRISPR knockout screen for autophagy in HEK293 cells with gene prioritization criteria.

prompt_templates.title: scRNA analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: Analyze this scRNA-seq dataset with quality control, clustering, and annotation. File path: ./data/sample.h5ad.

prompt_templates.title: GWAS interpretation
prompt_templates.prompt: Interpret GWAS summary stats for type 2 diabetes and run pathway enrichment. File: ./data/gwas.txt.

output_examples.input: Summarize ADMET risks for these three compounds and highlight any safety concerns.
output: Compound 1 shows low permeability and possible CYP inhibition requiring careful dosing
Compound 2 has moderate clearance and low predicted toxicity with acceptable safety margin
Compound 3 carries a potential hERG liability flag that warrants cardiac safety testing

best_practices: Provide clear file paths and data formats in prompts for accurate analysis
Start with a small test query before running long or expensive research workflows
Review generated code and results before making experimental decisions
anti_patterns: Running the agent without API keys properly configured
Assuming PDF output works without installing weasyprint or reportlab dependencies
Sharing .env files or committing API keys to public repositories

faq.question: Is this skill compatible with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code?
faq.answer: Yes, it supports all three platforms through configuration of Anthropic Claude models as the primary LLM provider.

faq.question: What limits should I expect when using this skill?
faq.answer: API rate limits depend on your provider. Large datasets may require more memory. Initial data download is approximately 11GB.

faq.question: Can I integrate external tools or databases?
faq.answer: Yes, biomni supports MCP server configuration for external tools like FDA drug databases and web search.

faq.question: How is my data handled?
faq.answer: All data and reports are stored locally on your machine in the directory you configure.

faq.question: What should I do if setup fails?
faq.answer: Verify conda is installed, check API keys are set correctly, and re-run the setup script with a simple test query.

faq.question: How does it compare to prompt-only tools?
faq.answer: Biomni can execute generated code for real analysis, not just provide text responses, enabling actual data processing.
